t: Proverbs 13
A*pn wise son hears his father’s instruction, but*ld a scoffer does not listen to rebuke.
From*ln the fruit of his mouth a man eats what is good, but*ld the desire of the treacherous is for violence.
Whoever*ln guards his mouth preserves his life; he*ld who opens wide his lips comes to ruin.
The*ln soul of the sluggard craves and gets nothing, while*ld the soul of the diligent is richly supplied.
The*ln righteous hates falsehood, but*ld the wicked brings shame and disgrace.
Righteousness*ln guards him whose way is blameless, but*ld sin overthrows the wicked.
One*ln pretends to be rich, yet has nothing; another*ld pretends to be poor, yet has great wealth.
The*ln ransom of a man’s life is his wealth, but*ld a poor man hears no threat.
The*ln light of the righteous rejoices, but*ld the lamp of the wicked will be put out.
By*ln insolence comes nothing but strife, but*ld with those who take advice is wisdom.
Wealth*ln gained hastily will dwindle, but*ld whoever gathers little by little will increase it.
Hope*ln deferred makes the heart sick, but*ld a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
Whoever*ln despises the word brings destruction on himself, but*ld he who reveres the commandment will be rewarded.
The*ln teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, that*ld one may turn away from the snares of death.
Good*ln sense wins favor, but*ld the way of the treacherous is their ruin.
Every*ln prudent man acts with knowledge, but*ld a fool flaunts his folly.
A*ln wicked messenger falls into trouble, but*ld a faithful envoy brings healing.
Poverty*ln and disgrace come to him who ignores instruction, but*ld whoever heeds reproof is honored.
A*ln desire fulfilled is sweet to the soul, but*ld to turn away from evil is an abomination to fools.
Whoever*ln walks with the wise becomes wise, but*ld the companion of fools will suffer harm.
Disaster*ln pursues sinners, but*ld the righteous are rewarded with good.
A*ln good man leaves an inheritance to his children’s children, but*ld the sinner’s wealth is laid up for the righteous.
The*ln fallow ground of the poor would yield much food, but*ld it is swept away through injustice.
Whoever*ln spares the rod hates his son, but*ld he who loves him is diligent to discipline him.
The*ln righteous has enough to satisfy his appetite, but*ld the belly of the wicked suffers want.
